timeline.bodyText:
(soft) 0) do we need the prefix "constraitnProvider"? It in the class ...ConstraintProviderTest

What method are we testing? Answer: "given". I 'd start with that.
I am not a fan of having the word "test" in methods that already have @test annotation.
Today I understand why this is an "integration" test. Because it does more integration than the other unit tests that just test one constraint. In 6 months from now I'll have forgotten that. Can we naming it something like "multipleConstraints"?

Therefore, these method name suggestions for these 2 tests:
givenSolutionMultipleConstraints
givenFactsMultipleConstraints
